full.title: Improved herbivore resistance in cultivated tomato with the sesquiterpene biosynthetic pathway from a wild relative.
full.authorString: Bleeker PM, Mirabella R, Diergaarde PJ, VanDoorn A, Tissier A, Kant MR, Prins M, de Vos M, Haring MA, Schuurink RC.

authorAffiliation.affiliation: Department of Plant Physiology, Swammerdam Institute of Life Sciences,  University of Amsterdam, 1098 XH Amsterdam,  The Netherlands.

journal.title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
journal.ISOAbbreviation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
journal.medlineAbbreviation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A

full.abstractText: Tomato breeding has been tremendously efficient in increasing fruit quality and quantity but did not focus on improving herbivore resistance. The biosynthetic pathway for the production of 7-epizingiberene in a wild tomato was introduced into a cultivated greenhouse variety with the aim to obtain herbivore resistance. 7-Epizingiberene is a specific sesquiterpene with toxic and repellent properties that is produced and stored in glandular trichomes. We identified 7-epizingiberene synthase (ShZIS) that belongs to a new class of sesquiterpene synthases, exclusively using Z-Z-farnesyl-diphosphate (zFPP) in plastids, probably arisen through neo-functionalization of a common ancestor. Expression of the ShZIS and zFPP synthases in the glandular trichomes of cultivated tomato resulted in the production of 7-epizingiberene. These tomatoes gained resistance to several herbivores that are pests of tomato. Hence, introduction of this sesquiterpene biosynthetic pathway into cultivated tomatoes resulted in improved herbivore resistance.
full.affiliation: Department of Plant Physiology, Swammerdam Institute of Life Sciences,  University of Amsterdam, 1098 XH Amsterdam,  The Netherlands.

title: Improved herbivore resistance in cultivated tomato with the sesquiterpene biosynthetic pathway from a wild relative.
